title: Arsenal want Juventus boss Max Allegri to take charge if Arsene Wenger leaves in the summer
text:
Arsenal want Juventus boss Max Allegri to take charge if Arsene Wenger leaves in the summer 
Ex-Milan chief tops Gunners shortlist including Dortmund's Thomas Tuchel and Atletico Madrid manager Diego Simeone Exclusive 3rd March 2017, 9:01 pm Updated: 3rd March 2017, 9:14 pm Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments ARSENAL want Juventus boss Max Allegri to take over if Arsene Wenger decides to leave at the end of the season. 
The Emirates boss is set to decide his future in the next few weeks, and has a two-year deal on the table which will take him into his 23rd season with the Gunners . Reuters 5 Juventus manager Max Allegri is thought to head the wishlist of the Arsenal board should long-serving boss Arsene Wenger leave in the summer 
But he has faced a huge fans backlash in recent seasons, and has been heavily criticised this term after his side all but dropped out of the title race after a string of poor performances. 
Keep up to date with ALL the Arsenal gossip and transfers on our club page plus fixtures, results and live match commentary 
Arsenal ‘s board have already drawn up a shortlist of managers who could take over from him, including Dortmund ‘s Thomas Tuchel and Atletico Madrid ‘s Diego Simeone . 
They also like Monaco’s Leonardo Jardim who has had a stunning season so far with the Ligue 1 side. 
But it is understood Allegri is their top target, and should Wenger not commit to an extension, he is the man they want to become the new Gunners chief. 
The Italian coach is also thought to be interested in a move to the Premier League, as he looks for a new challenge in Europe. 
He has also fallen out with a number of Juventus stars, and this is almost certain to be his last season with the Old Lady. Getty Images The future of Gunners boss Arsene Wenger beyond this season is uncertain Getty Images Dortmund head coach Thomas Tuchel is also one of the fancied contenders Getty Images 5 Atletico Madrid chief Diego Simeone is admired for the job he has done in La Liga 
Wenger , 67, revealed earlier this month he will announce whether he will stay at Arsenal in late March or early April. 
The Frenchmen, who took over in 1996, said: “My preference is always to manage Arsenal and I’ve shown that throughout my time here.

He also had a run-in with striker Paulo Dybala who snubbed his handshake after he was substituted in a 2-0 win over Sassuolo in January.
